III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description
1

(1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/22/25, the youth attended a talent show outside on campus.
A youth dented a staff member's car and other youth pointed at a
particular youth as the culprit. The staff member who owned the
vehicle told the youth that they should bust the youth in the face.
The youth went AWOL for 20 minutes due to not feeling safe.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 6/24/25. There
were no additional concerns reported.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on 6/25/2025 at
Wolverine. Youth A refused to discuss the allegations and
concerns regarding his safety. Youth A reported talking about the
incident would only get him beat up by his peers again. Youth A
did not want to disclose who would want to harm him. He was
adamant about not talking. After asking youth about the talent
show and the staff who was present, Youth A dismissed himself
from the interview.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 6/25/2025 at
Wolverine. Youth B reported being present at the Talent Show
and he also reported witnessing Youth A get upset following the
Talent Show. Youth B reported Youth A got upset because he did
not receive a trophy. Youth A reported he did not witness any staff
member threaten Youth A. Youth B reported going AWOL with
Youth C right after the Talent Show so he was not present to
witness Youth A interactions with staff. Youth B denied making
threats to Youth A. Youth B reported he did not witness Youth A
damage vehicles.
Youth C was interviewed face to face on 6/25/25 at Wolverine.
Youth C reported participating in the talent show. Youth C
reported he did not see Youth A get upset and he did not witness
Youth A leave the premises. Youth C reported he did not hear any
staff member talk disrespectfully to Youth A.
2

Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face on 6/25/2025 at
Wolverine. Supervisor 1 reported being the supervisor on shift the
evening of the talent show. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was
upset that he did not win an award at the Talent Show.
Supervisor 1 reported Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C went AWOL
after the talent show. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A had been
displaying behaviors all day. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A had
two Line of Sight violations until Youth A finally went AWOL.
Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 and Supervisor 2 followed Youth A
down the street until he passed Charlevoix Street. Supervisor 1
reported Youth A was probably gone from the facility for 40
minutes. Supervisor 1 reported at the end of her shift, she left out
the back door and saw Youth A sitting at the back door and
allowed him to come back in. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was
free of marks and bruises. Youth A reported a peer said
something mean to him but did not disclose the name. Supervisor
1 reported Youth A made threats to throw rocks at the staff cars
and he would flip everyone’s cars over but did not see Youth A do
the damage. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 and Supervisor 2 did
not threaten Youth A when trying to de-escalate him.
Vice President sent email on 7/9/2025 of the staff who were
present the day of the talent show. According to Vice President,
Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 were on schedule the day of
the Talent Show. It should be noted that Staff 1 was not
mentioned as a staff present during the Talent Show. This
information was clarified after review of incident report.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face-to-face at Wolverine on
7/28/25. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C
went AWOL following the Talent Show. He also reported Youth A
went out of line of sight twice before going AWOL. Supervisor 2
reported each time Youth A returned to the facility, he brought
back weapons, including sticks, rocks, and a rusty nail file, which
he used to threaten staff. Supervisor 2 reported his vehicle was
not damaged during the incident, and Youth A did not threaten to
damage it. Supervisor 2 reported he and Staff 1 intervened by
retrieving the weapons from Youth A, taking them directly from his
hands. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A went AWOL the third time,
again moving out of staff’s line of sight. Supervisor 2 and Staff 1
followed Youth A to the corner of Lenox and Charlevoix in an
effort to redirect him, but Youth A did not respond to their attempts
and continued walking up the street and behind a church.
Supervisor 2 reported once Youth A went AWOL, Supervisor 2
notified the team. Supervisor 2 reported Staff 1 later reported
Youth A returned to the facility without informing anyone. Youth A
3

was found sitting by the back door. Supervisor 2 reported seeing
Youth A as he was ending his shift. Supervisor 2 reported Youth A
did not explain why he went AWOL and did not report being
threatened by Staff 1. Supervisor 2 reported having no concerns
regarding Staff 1’s interactions with Youth A during the incident.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on 7/30/2025. Staff 1
reported being present on the day of the talent show and was
called to the building to assist Supervisor 2 with Youth A. Staff 1
reported observing Youth A holding a rusty nail file and
threatening staff. He also reported Youth A threatened to damage
Supervisor 2’s car, but did not follow through. Staff 1 reported
Youth A was outside the front of the building and walked toward
the employee parking lot, but he did not see Youth A cause any
damage to Supervisor 2’s vehicle. Staff 1 reported he alerted
Supervisor 1 Youth A was attempting to damage the vehicle. He
reported Supervisor 2 came out of the building to check on his car,
and the two of them continued to follow Youth A up the street
before he went AWOL. Staff 1 reported verbal attempts were
made to prevent Youth A from leaving. He also reported he did not
hear Supervisor 2 make any threats toward Youth A. Staff 1
confirmed he followed the AWOL protocol after Youth A went
AWOL.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face on 7/28/25. Staff 2
reported being present at the Talent Show and did not see Youth
A damage vehicles. Staff 3 reported he did not witness any staff
members threaten Youth A. Staff 3 reported he has not heard
Staff 1 or Supervisor 2 speak disrespectfully to Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 7/29/25. Staff 3
reported being on shift the day of the talent show. Staff 3 reported
Youth A did not participate in the Talent Show but he was present.
Staff 3 reported she saw Youth A upset but was uncertain as to
what he was upset about. Staff 3 reporting witnessing Youth A
outside of the building screaming and yelling but she could not
make out what he was saying. Staff 3 reported she overheard
some staff saying Youth A was threatening to damage vehicles,
but she did not witness Youth A damage the vehicles or receive
information that any staff person vehicle was damaged.
Staff 4 was contacted via telephone on 7/28/25, 7/30/25,
7/31/25 but was unsuccessful.
Staff 5 was contacted via telephone on 7/28/25 and 7/30/25.
However, the telephone number provided was disconnected.
4

Therapist was contacted on 6/25/25 via telephone. Therapist
reported Youth A disclosed concerns regarding threats being
made to harm the youth by an unknown staff member. According
to the therapist, Youth A did not disclose the name of the staff
member who threatened him. Therapist reported he has not
witnessed any staff member threaten Youth A and he has not
received any reports of Youth A damaging a vehicle.
Foster Care Specialist was contacted via telephone on
7/31/25. Foster Care specialist reported no concerns for Youth A
at Wolverine. Foster Care Specialist reported there being a
Placement Care Unit meeting with MDHHS and Wolverine held on
6/26/25 in which a safety plan was established. The safety plan is
as follows:
• Staff members will under no circumstances threaten Youth
A. Staff members will ensure responses to Youth A are
respectful and appropriate.
• Staff members will utilize Youth A’s Behavioral Response
Plan provided by DHHS to deescalate Youth A should he
demonstrate challenging behaviors.
• Staff members will provide choices for Youth A when he is
triggered or not following directions.
• Youth A will remain respectful to staff members.
• Youth A will not put his hands on or abuse property that is
not his.
• Youth A will agree not to go AWOL.
• Youth A will not put his hands on staff members or peers.
• Youth A will do his best to make safer choices. Youth A will
practice coping skills such as writing or asking staff
members if he can go for a walk with staff members on
campus.
• Youth A will do his best to be a positive leader to his peers
and make choices that are safe for everyone.
Residential Director (RD) was interviewed face to face on
7/28/2025. RD reported no staff reported receiving damage to
their vehicle during the night of the talent show or thereafter. RD
reported Staff 1 was terminated for an incident unrelated to this
investigation. It should be noted that during the interview with
Staff 1, it was reported he was not terminated from Wolverine.
Documents:
Incident Report Dated 6/21/25 authored by Supervisor 2 was
reviewed on 7/29/25. Incident report is consistent with Supervisor
5

1 interview. Incident report documents Supervisor 2 and Staff 1
interactions with Youth A prior to AWOL. Incident Report
documents Youth A body chart which indicates no marks or
bruises. Incident Report also documents Youth A refusal of
medical services. There is no mention of Youth A making threats
to a vehicle or staff reporting damage to their vehicle.
Staff 1’s personnel file: Staff 1 was terminated on 6/30/25 for
attendance. Staff 1 Received disciplinary action on 1/10/24 for
erratic behavior, Violation of company rules, violation of safety
rules, and unsatisfactory work performance. Staff 1 admitted to
using inappropriate communication with clients. Staff 1 was placed
on a 3-day suspension. Staff 1 was disciplined and placed on
administrative leave for allowing a client to use a T Mobile hot
spot. Staff 1 completed CPI training on 8/14/25, Boundaries, Line
of Sight, and Engagement training on 11/26/24, and Appropriate
Behavior Management Techniques and EAP Services,
Appropriate Communication with Youth on 3/18/25.
Behavior Support policy: Behavior Support Policy: This policy
provides an overview on how staff members provide immediate
emotional and environmental support to clients in crisis so that
stress and the risk for violence are reduced. Staff are to utilize
Non-Violent restrictive interventions that follow the Crisis
Prevention Institute (CPl), Non-Violent Crisis Intervention Model.
Critical incident reports are to be completed whenever a CPI
intervention was used. Staff are required to complete a Behavior
Notification whenever an incident or event occurs which is out of
the ordinary and the use of non-violent physical intervention did
not occur. Non-violent physical restrictions are never to be used
as a form of punishment, discipline, ensuring compliance,
demonstrating authority, or retaliation. They are only used to
protect clients or others from unanticipated or severely aggressive
behavior that places them at serious threat of violence or injury
if no immediate intervention occurs.
Staff members are to continuously monitor the client to ensure
safety and assess for any harmful health or psychological
reactions. If a client being physically controlled appears to be in
physical distress, immediate notification of the Program Manager
or designee is to occur, and the nonviolent physical intervention
technique is discontinued. Immediate medical evaluation is
required under these circumstances. In the event a client displays
an altered mental status, immediate notification of Program
Manager or designee is to occur and when it is determined to be
6

safe the non-violent physical intervention technique is
discontinued.
The use and choice of all non-violent physical interventions must
be guided by a number of factors
including the following:
l. The need to ensure the safety of other clients and staff.
2. The size and strength of the client to be restrained.
3. The nature and degree of past violent behavior by the client.
4. Whether or not the client has a weapon.
5. Physical or health conditions other client to be restrained.
6. The client's individual Crisis Management Plan (ICMP).
Truancy Policy: When a truancy occurs, the following steps will
be taken:
1. Staff will make efforts to verbally redirect the truanting client
and will offer the client support and alternatives to truancy.
a. If a non-supervising staff is available, they will
walk with the client and continue to provide
verbal support and redirection encouraging the
client not to truant.
b. Staff will not physically intervene with the
client on WHS property other than in accordance
with CPI protocol regarding danger to self or
others.
2. Staff supervising the group will immediately call a group
attention to support and maintain the security of the group.
3. Staff will maintain control of the group and conduct an
immediate head count.
4. Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist
Supervisor on duty when line of sight is lost, no later than
15 from loss of line of sight (when youth is determined
AWOL).
5. The Youth Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead
Supervisor and Program Management who will provide
oversight for incident management.
6. The youth specialist supervisor will ensure law enforcement
is notified immediately (no more than 5 minutes from when
youth is determined AWOL.
7. Staff will report the following information immediately to the
Youth Care Specialist Supervisor on duty;
a Name(s) of the truant client(s).
b. Approximate time and location of the truancy.
c. The direction of travel the client(s) was/were headed.
7

d. Whether the client(s) appear(s) to present a danger to self
or others in the community.
e. Circumstances prior to the truancy, risk assessment and
other pertinent safety related information.
8. Truancy Notification: In event a client truants from WHS
property or from a home pass the following notifications
will be made;
a. Program Manager or Director (immediately)
b. Local law enforcement agency (immediately)
Analysis The agency was found to be in compliance based on incident
reports and staff interviews. There was no documentation
indicating that Youth A damaged a staff vehicle. Youth A refused
to participate in the interview. Following the Talent Show on
6/21/25, Youth A went AWOL. According to staff interviews,
appropriate efforts were made to de escalate the situation. Based
on staff and youth interviews, no staff member was seen or heard
making threats toward Youth A. Additionally, Youth A was not
observed causing damage to any staff members vehicles.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
